coredata.dc:title: Stable solid electrolyte interphase induced by Ag@graphite dual-functional layer in lithium metal anode

coredata.dc:description: The thermodynamically unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film and infinite volume expansion during the plating/stripping of lithium metal anode (LMA) are important reasons for inhibiting the cycle lifespan of lithium metal batteries (LMBs). It is of great significance to introduce a SEI similar to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) on the LMA to improve the lifespan of LMBs. In this work, the graphite was cleverly covered on the LMA to induce the formation of a uniform and stable SEI, protect Li metal and obtain a stable anode interface. Moreover, a thin silver (Ag) layer with excellent lithiophilic and conductivity was introduced before covering graphite to improve the migration kinetics of Li+ ions in the graphite layer. Under the synergistic effect of them, a stable SEI was successfully induced and the volume change of LMA was reduced. As a result, LMBs modified by Ag-Graphite layer (Ag-Graphite@Li) have showed better electrochemical properties. And Ag-Graphite@Li anode//NCM523 cell could maintain a capacity retention of 78.3 % for 400 cycles at 0.5 C in carbonate-based electrolytes. This work provides an effective strategy for improving the cycle lifespan of LMBs.

Graphite

Dual-functional Layer
Induced stable SEI

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) Schematic diagram of cycling scene of conventional Li metal anode. (b) Schematic diagram of Li metal anode cycle decorated by Ag and graphite layer. Schematic diagrams of (c) coating graphite layer and (d) vacuum evaporation deposition Ag layer.

Optical pictures of (a) pristine Li and (b) Ag-Graphite@Li foil. (c) Weigiht increase record of coated graphite on the Li metal anode. (d) SEM image and (g) XRD patterns of pristine Li foil. (e) SEM image and (h) XRD patterns of pristine Ag modified Li foil. (f) SEM image and (i) XRD patterns of Ag@Graphite Li foil.

Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of (a) Li||Ag-Graphite@Cu foil, (b) Li||Graphite@Cu foil and (c) Li||Cu foli at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1. (d) XPS spectrum of C 1 s of Ag-Graphite@Li foil with different etching times. (e) XPS spectrum of F 1 s of Ag-Graphite@Li foil with different etching times. (f) XPS spectrum of of O 1 s Ag-Graphite@Li foil with different etching times.

XRD patterns of (a) Ag-Graphite@Li foil and (b) pristine graphite modified Li foil after depositing different capacity Li metal. (c) Time voltage curve of Ag-Graphite@Li||Li symmetric battery at 1.0 mA cm−2 in discharge condition. (d) Optical pictures of Li deposition on the Ag-Graphite@Li foil at 1.0 mA cm−2 in discharge condition. (e) Time voltage curve of Graphite@Li||Li symmetric battery at 1.0 mA cm−2 in discharge condition. (f) Optical pictures of Li deposition on the Graphite@Li foil at 1.0 mA cm−2 in discharge condition. (g) Time voltage curve of Li||Li symmetric battery at 1.0 mA cm−2 in discharge condition. (h) Optical pictures of Li deposition on the pristine Li foil at 1.0 mA cm−2 in discharge condition.

In-situ EIS spectrum of the (a) pristine Li metal anode, (b) Graphite@Li anode and (c) Ag-Graphite@Li anode at different cycles. (d) Three LMAs symmetrical batteries time-voltage curves. The time-voltage curve of pristine Li metal anode at (e1) 400–408 h and (e2) 1200–1208 h. The time-voltage curve of Graphite@Li anode at (f1) 400–408 h and (f2) 1200–1208 h. The time-voltage curve of Ag-Graphite@Li anode at (g1) 400–408 h and (g2) 1200–1208 h.

(a) The cycling performance of pristine Li foil, Graphite@Li foil and Ag-Graphite@Li foil with NCM523 cathode at a rate of 0.5 C. The voltage profiles of (b) Ag-Graphite@Li foil, (e) Graphite@Li foil and (h) pristine Li foil at the rate of 0.5 C at different cycles. SEM images of (c) Ag-Graphite@Li foil, (f) Graphite@Li foil and (i) pristine Li foil after 10 cycles. SEM images of (d) Ag-Graphite@Li foil, (g) Graphite@Li foil and (j) pristine Li foil after 50 cycles.

head.ce:title: Stable solid electrolyte interphase induced by Ag@graphite dual-functional layer in lithium metal anode

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The thermodynamically unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film and infinite volume expansion during the plating/stripping of lithium metal anode (LMA) are important reasons for inhibiting the cycle lifespan of lithium metal batteries (LMBs). It is of great significance to introduce a SEI similar to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) on the LMA to improve the lifespan of LMBs. In this work, the graphite was cleverly covered on the LMA to induce the formation of a uniform and stable SEI, protect Li metal and obtain a stable anode interface. Moreover, a thin silver (Ag) layer with excellent lithiophilic and conductivity was introduced before covering graphite to improve the migration kinetics of Li+ ions in the graphite layer. Under the synergistic effect of them, a stable SEI was successfully induced and the volume change of LMA was reduced. As a result, LMBs modified by Ag-Graphite layer (Ag-Graphite@Li) have showed better electrochemical properties. And Ag-Graphite@Li anode//NCM523 cell could maintain a capacity retention of 78.3 % for 400 cycles at 0.5 C in carbonate-based electrolytes. This work provides an effective strategy for improving the cycle lifespan of LMBs.

ce:section.ce:para: In modern society, electrochemical energy storage devices are an important basis for realizing automobile electrification, which requires batteries to have a large energy and power densities and a long lifespan [1–4]. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are one of the best options, and they have been commercialized in large quantities [5–8]. However, due to the mileage concerns about electric vehicles have always existed, LMBs with higher energy and power densities have gradually gained a lot of attention [9–11].

The thermodynamically unstable SEI and the large volume change during the plating/stripping of LMA are the main reasons for the short lifespan in LMBs [12–14]. Firstly, Li metal with extremely high reactivity will directly react with electrolyte to form a complex SEI. And the deposited Li will continuously generate new SEI during the charging process, which will increase the thickness of SEI and interface resistance [15–18]. Meanwhile, the increase of interface resistance will affect the transport behavior of Li+ ions, resulting in the formation of lithium dendrites. In addition to the SEI film generated by the chemical reaction, thermodynamically unstable organic electrolytes and Li salts will also been decomposed at low potential to form SEI during the electrochemical cycle. The composite SEI generated by chemical reactions and electrochemical reactions is complex and unstable [19–21]. Therefore, this kind of SEI cannot form a stable interface on the LMA, which reduces the electrochemical performance of LMBs. Finally, Since the Li deposition is a hostless process, which will produce a huge volume change on the anode. Such a huge volume change will cause the SEI to continue to rupture and regenerate, which will further aggravate the instability of SEI. Therefore, a SEI with stable structure and clear composition on the anode is of great significance to improve the electrochemical performance of LMBs [16,22].

In contrast, LIBs have a more stable SEI on the graphite anode and a longer cycle life than LMBs. This is because Li+ ions are intercalated in the graphite layer to provide capacity in LIBs [23–26]. It means that there is no Li metal generation during the cycling process, which can effectively avoid the directly reaction between Li and electrolyte to form unstable SEI [10,27–29]. And the SEI is mainly from the electrochemical reaction of electrolyte at a low potential during the first or previous cycles and it is mainly induced by graphite anode. Meanwhile, the insertion and removal of Li+ ions will not result in a huge volume change for graphite anode, which means that SEI can remain stable during the cycle [30]. Because a strong and stable SEI layer can be formed on the graphite anode, conventional LIBs can undergo thousands of stable cycles in carbonate electrolytes.

By learning from the advantages of graphite anode in LIBs, introducing a thin graphite layer on the LMA to protect Li metal and induce the formation of stable SEI layer is also an effective strategy to improve the electrochemical performance of LMBs. The graphite layer on the anode is used to induce a stable SEI and improve the electrochemical performance of LMBs [25,31–33]. There were some research going on to introduce carbon materials into the surface of LMA. For example, Zheng et al [34]. construct a stable carbon nanosphere layer directly on the LMA. This layer can maintain stability and non-rupture during the Li plating/stripping to protect the LMA. Sun et al [27]. introduce massive artificial graphite (MAG) to the anode. And the MAG can not only achieve the insertion of Li+ ions, but also use the gaps to store and protect Li metal, which greatly increase the battery capacity. Meanwhile, this MAG can also induce a stable SEI on the anode. Therefore, in this work, a thin graphite layer was cleverly introduced on the LMA surface by manual coating to induce the formation of a stable SEI similar to LIBs.

However, due to the slow kinetic behavior of Li+ ions in the graphite layer, it is very facile for Li+ ions to obtain electrons directly on the graphite surface at high current densities, which will result in Li metal precipitation [35–37]. And once Li precipitation occurs, it will hinder the role of the graphite layer. Therefore, some strategies are needed to improve the kinetic behavior of Li+ ions in the graphite layer. And metal Ag was widely used in LMBs due to its excellent electrical conductivity and lithiophilic. For instance, Ag nanoparticles were pressed into the LMA to drive Li+ ions to migrate and deposition into the interior of LMA by pressing Ag nanoparticles into the LMA by Wang et al [38]. Liu et al [39]. achieved rapid migration of Li+ ions into the graphite layer and uniform Li deposition by introducing Ag nanoparticles into graphene. These works have shown that Ag has a strong ability to effectively improve the migration of Li+ ions.

Therefore, in this work, a dual-functional interface layer that can not only induce the formation of a stable SEI but further the transport of Li+ ions on the anode was introduced into the LMA surface. The functional layer consists of a graphite layer by manual coating and an Ag layer by vacuum evaporation ( Fig. 1(c) and (d)). Graphite layer can induce a SEI film with a clear composition and stable structure in the carbonate electrolyte to provide a stable interface for the LMA. Meanwhile, Ag layer can increase the migration rate of Li+ ions in the graphite layer, so that metal Li will deposit into the graphite layer. This effect can avoid the occurrence of Li precipitation and the volume expansion of Li deposition (Fig. 1(b)). The synergy of them can make the plating and stripping of Li metal more controllable and construct a stable SEI, which can help to achieve a long cycle lifespan for LMBs. And this work provides a viable strategy for the future application of LMBs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Ag layer introduced by vacuum evaporation deposition
ce:section.ce:para: Li foil was selected with a diameter of 12 mm and a thickness of 1 mm. Silver scraping rod was used to remove oxide film and impurities on the Li metal surface. Then Li foil was pasted on the sample stage and placed into the vacuum evaporation machine (Electron Beam Evaporation System, DE Technology DE400). And Ag rods were put into a heated crucible, the machine was vacuumed. After the evacuation was complete, the crucible began to heat up to melt Ag for evaporation. The deposition speed was 0.5 nm s−1 and time was 100 s. Thus, a 50 nm Ag layer of was deposited on the Li metal surface. Finally, break the vacuum and remove the Li foil from machine. All of the above operations were achieved in an inert (Ar) atmosphere glove box.

The pencil core was used as graphite source and graphite was cut into a conical shape. Then the sides of graphite core were in contact with Li foil that coated Ag layer, and graphite was evenly and completely covered on the Ag layer with a uniform and light force. Finally, the Li metal surface was coated with graphite completely.

X-ray diffraction spectroscopy was used to test the phase formed (Rigaku, Miniflex 600, Cu Kα, λ= 0.154 nm). The samples morphologies and elemental analysis were showed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Zeiss Gemini SEM 500) and energy spectrometer (EDS, Ultim extreme, Oxford)) respectively. Photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher, Escalab Xi+) was used to test the elemental valence and composition of the SEI after cycling. The in-situ optical microscope pictures were taken to observe the Li deposition position on different substrates by the Optical microscope (Olympus, Japan).

The coin cells (CR2032) were equipped to test the electrochemical properties such as coulombic efficiency, cycle lifespan and impedance value. The electrolyte was ethylene carbonate (EC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC) as the solvent (1:1 in volume), lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6, 1 M) as the solute, and fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC, 10 wt%) as electrolyte additive. Three kinds of symmetrical battery which were Ag and Graphite modified Li foil (Ag-Graphite@Li), pristine Graphite modified Li foil (Graphite@Li) and pristine Li foil were assembled to test their cycle performance and impedance before and after cycling. The above three LMAs were equipped with LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 (NCM523, mass loading was about 13.5–14.0 mg cm−2) to test half-battery performance. High-voltage resistant NCM523 was selected as the cathode, acetylene black was used as the conductive agent, and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) was binder. NCM523, acetylene black and PVDF were then mixed at a mass of 94:3:3 in N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP). The slurry was evenly coated on the aluminum foil, dried and beaten into round pieces (12 mm in diameter). A Neware battery tester was used to carry out electrochemical performance at 25 °C. And Celgard 2500 separators (18 mm in diameter) were added to the battery and each cell used 75 μL of electrolyte. All of the assemble operations were achieved in an inert (Ar) atmosphere glove box. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves were measured by the electrochemical workstation (CHI660E, Chenhua). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were obtained from Solartron 1287/1260 (from 10 mHz to 100 kHz).

The surfaces of pristine Li foil, Ag@Li foil and Ag-Graphite@Li foil were characterized. It can be seen that the pristine Li surface was relatively smooth and flat ( Fig. 2(d)). And Ag nanoparticles have covered on the Li metal surface after evaporating (Fig. 2(e)). Evaporation was by heating and melting Ag rods and forming Ag particles vapor to coat the substrate surface, and finally an interface composed of Ag NPs was formed on the lithium foil surface. In Fig. 2(h), it showed that Li metal surface is all Ag layer and there were no Li diffraction peaks. The graphite layer was then introduced over the Ag layer by hand coating (Fig. 2(f)). When graphite was coated, the XRD diffraction peak on Ag-Gr aphite@Li foil surface was mainly the peak of the graphite (Fig. 2(i)). Meanwhile, the amount of graphite coated on the Li foil was about 0.21 mg cm−2 (Fig. 2(c)), and the thickness of the coating was several micron levels.

Cyclic voltammetry (CV) test was used to indicate the transport and deposition process of Li+ ions on different anodes. Therefore, Cu foil was treated by different ways was assembled with Li metal into a half-battery for cyclic voltammetry (CV) test. In the CV curve of Ag and graphite-modified Cu foil, it had a pair of pronounced redox peaks around 0.1 V ( Fig. 3(a)). This pair of peaks indicated that the insertion and removal of Li+ ions in the graphite layer was reversible. This is mainly due to the induction of Ag layer, which to cause Li+ ions to migrate to the interior and achieve stable insertion and removal in the graphite layer. The peaks on the Cu foil modified by graphite alone were not obvious (Fig. 3(b)), resulting in Li+ ions being unable to achieve stable insertion and removal behavior in the graphite layer, but are more likely to be deposited directly on the graphite surface. For pristine Cu foil, the main peaks were from the oxidation or reduction decomposition of the solvent in the electrolyte (Fig. 3(c)). Further, there are no reversible peaks of alloying and dealloying in Fig. 3(a). This indicated that Ag layer was only involved in the process of inducing Li+ ions to penetrate graphite, and would not participate in the actual electrochemical reaction, nor will provide capacity on the anode. Therefore, the tests of these CV curves can prove that the penetrable deposition of Li+ ions in the graphite layer can be achieved when the Ag and graphite layers were modified at the same time on the anode. This deposition behavior can reduce the volume change of Li deposition and contributes to the formation of a stable electrolytic/electrolyte interface.

XPS was used to analyze the SEI composition and variation of the interfaces of the three LMAs during cycling. The film-forming properties of different LMAs after 50 cycles with symmetrical cells were studied in this type of ordinary carbonate electrolyte with EC and DEC as solvents, LiPF6 as salt and FEC as additive. From the C 1 s spectrum, it can be seen that the peaks centered on 284.8 eV, 286.7 eV, 288.7 eV and 290.2 eV belong to C-C, C-OR, COOR and CO3 2-, respectively. Ag-Graphite@Li foil at different depths showed stable C-C, C-O and COOR peaks (Fig. 3(d)). The peak intensity of CO3 2- gradually strengthened with the increase of etching depth. And Li-C peak appeared when the etching time reached 150 s (Fig. S1(g)). Combining the three etching depths, the SEI film on Ag-Graphite@Li foil can maintain the relative stability of the species and composition. The reason was that the induction of the Ag layer causes Li+ to deposit in the inner layer of graphite, which avoided the unwanted side reactions between exposed metal Li and electrolyte and inhomogeneity of SEI film distribution. Meanwhile, the graphite layer on the surface can also promote the rapid and uniform film formation of carbonate electrolyte, and finally contribute of SEI components more uniform and stable. On Graphite@Li foil, the C-C, C-O, and COOR peaks on the surface were exposed stabilized (Fig. S1(b)). With the increase of etching depth, the relative content of C-O and COOR began to decrease and were accompanied by a rapid increase in the content of CO3 2-. And the peak of Li-C appeared earlier (Fig. S1(e), (h)). The composition changes are more drastic at different etching depths. Due to the uneven deposition of Li metal directly on the graphite layer surface, the deposited Li reacted directly with the electrolyte to produce an uneven SEI film. Then this SEI layer was mixed with the SEI generated by electrolyte decomposition in the later battery cycle, resulting in complex and uneven distribution of interface components on Graphite@Li foil. This uneven electrode-electrolyte interface makes it impossible for Li+ ions to reach the interface uniformly, which further aggravates the uneven Li deposition and causes the rapid decline of battery electrochemical performance. On the pure Li foil surface, the peaks of C-C, C-O, and COOR remain present (Fig. S1(c)). However, the peak of CO3 2- began to appear after 75 s of etching and the relative content of CO3 2- showed high level (Fig. S1(f)). When etched to 150 s, the peak of Li-C appeared (Fig. S1(i)). Combining the C 1 s spectra at three different depths, a new SEI component every time a depth was increased on the pure Li foil, which showed that the composition of SEI was uneven and unstable. It can also be seen that the distribution of its surface SEI conforms to the mosaic model, that is, the components were mosaic with each other. Based on the C 1 s spectra of the above three LMAs, it can be seen that the SEI on Ag-Graphite@Li foil has a more definite and stable composition and more uniform distribution than other anodes. It is also shown that the constructed Ag-Graphite@Li foil anode can effectively promote the uniform Li deposition and induce the formation of more stable SEI film.

From the F 1 s spectrum, the peaks centered at 684.8 eV and 687.0 eV correspond to Li-F and LixPyOFz, respectively, which are generally considered to be the chemical decomposition products of LiPF6. This reaction was mainly controlled by potential, thus the main components of SEI film on the three LMAs were LiF and LixPyOFz. Meanwhile, due to the composition of the SEI was more uniform, the distribution and relative content of the two components at different depths was relatively uniform on Ag-Graphite@Li foil (Fig. 3(e)). However, the relative content of these two components was more unevenly distributed at different depths on Graphite@Li foil (Fig. S2(b), (e) and (h)) pure Li foil (Fig. S2(c), (f) and (i)). And from the O 1 s spectrum, the peaks centered at 528.1 eV, 531.1 eV and 533.7 eV correspond to Li2O, ROLi and C-O, respectively. The distribution of oxygen elements on Ag-Graphite@Li foil was relatively uniform, and the relative content of Li2O in the SEI was low and the change with depth was weak (Fig. S3(a), (d) and (g)). However, for Graphite@Li foil and pristine Li foil the relative content of Li2O began to increase greatly with the deepening of etching depth, and the O 1 s spectrum composition changed significantly (Fig. S3). In general, Li2O is mainly formed by the reaction of metal Li with electrolyte. Due to the embedded deposition of Li+ ions, there was no obvious Li precipitation of during deposition and metal Li was effectively protected, the relative content of Li2O in SEI was lower than other two anodes on Ag-Graphite@Li foil. Through XPS analysis, it can be seen that the composition of SEI film on Ag-Graphite@Li foil was more stable and the distribution was more uniform, which was contributed to achieve a better electrochemical performance of LMBs.

And the key to this work is to keep Li deposited in the inner layer of graphite. Therefore, Li metal of different capacities have been deposited at a current of 1.0 mA cm−2 to explore Li deposition behaviors on Ag-Graphite@Li, Graphite@Li and pristine Li anodes (Fig. S4). Half of round Li foil surface was treated with Ag and graphite, and the other was kept as fresh Li metal. It could be seen that there was no Li precipitation on the Ag-Graphite@Li foil before the deposition amount was less than 1 mAh cm−2 (Fig. S4(a), (b), (c)). Li precipitation began to occur only when the capacity increased to 2 mAh cm−2 (Fig. S4(d)). Increasing the current density of deposition will make Li precipitate earlier (Fig. S4(g), (h), (i)). It can be clearly seen that under the induction of the Ag layer, some Li+ ions can be deposited in the inner layer of graphite to protect the deposited Li metal. Therefore, this deposition behavior can guarantee the functioning of the modification layer.

The surface phase was analyzed with different capacities Li deposited on Ag-Graphite@Li foil, Graphite@Li foil and pristine Li foil surface. XRD spectra showed the diffraction peak of metallic Li appears on the Graphite@Li foil only when deposited capacity reached 1.5 mAh cm−2 ( Fig. 4(a) and Fig. S5(c)), and the rest phase was mainly LixC. The phase of LiC6 on its surface always maintains a high content (Fig. S5(b)). On the Graphite@Li foil, the diffraction peak of Li metal has appeared when the capacity was 1 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 4(b) and Fig. S5(f)), indicating that Li precipitation has appeared at this time. And when the depositied capacity was 2 mAh cm−2, the relative content of Li metal was much higher than Ag-Graphite@Li foil (Fig. S5(c), (f)). For comparison, Li metal was also deposited on the pristine graphite anode to see the conditions of its surface phase. For pristine graphite anode, because its capacity was higher than deposition capacity, there will be no obvious Li precipitation phenomenon (Fig. S5(a)). The different surface phase of Li deposition on the Ag@Graphite Li anode mean that the form of Li+ ions transport and Li deposition behaviors were different from Graphite@Li anode and pristine graphite anode. It showed that Li+ ions can be deposited in the inner layer of graphite layer due to the induction of Ag layer. However, due to the lack of induction, Li+ ions have no driving force for downward movement after reaching the graphite surface and tend to precipitate directly on the Graphite@Li foil surface. When Li metal is successfully induced to be deposited inside, it will be protected well to inhibit the reaction between Li metal and electrolyte effectively, which can reduce the consumption of active substances in the battery system. Meanwhile, graphite layer covered can also induce a stable SEI layer and further construct a stable electrode-electrolyte interface to achieve a longer cycle lifespan of LMBs.

Light microscopy was used to observe the Li deposition behavior over time in an in-situ cell. Deposition was performed using the galvanostatic method with a current density of 1 mA cm−2. The working electrodes were the above three kinds of LMA, and the counter electrode and reference electrode were pristine Li foil. On the Ag-Graphite@Li foil, it exhibited a penetrable deposition. The time-voltage curve of Ag-Graphite@Li anode showed that the process was of Li intercalation. After 100 minutes, as the discharge time increased, the voltage curve indicated that the lithium metal began to be deposited with the formation of Li metal (Fig. 4(c)). With the increase of deposition capacity, the volume of the deposition layer gradually expanded, but it was always deposited in the inner layer of graphite. A relatively uniform deposition was achieved (Fig. 4(d)). This phenomenon continues until the deposition time is 40 minutes, when the deposition time reaches 50 minutes, the Li metal began to precipitate on the surface of the modified graphite. The reason may be that the induction of Ag layer gradually weakened as the thickness of Li deposited increase. It may also be that the volume expansion caused by Li deposition exceeded the limit that the graphite layer can withstand, causing the graphite layer to break. Eventually, Li was deposited directly on the rupture sites. However, the time-voltage curve of Graphite@Li anode showed a clear nucleation process in the first 10 minutes. And then the curve changed to flat, which represented the process of Li metal deposition (Fig. 4(e)). As a result, the optical photographs have appeared a clear Li metal deposition on the Graphite@Li foi at the beginning (Fig. 4(f)). This is due to the loss of lithophilic Ag nanoparticles and the excellent conductivity of graphite made that it was easy for Li+ ions to be deposited directly on the graphite surface for the Graphite@Li foil. Finally, a number of Li+ ions reached the anode were directly deposited on the graphite surface without a penetrable deposition. With the increase of deposition time, the deposition behavior of Li metal gradually developed in an uneven deposition. And the time-voltage curve of pristine Li anode also showed a clear nucleation process and deposition process (Fig. 4(g)). Due to there was no surface modification on the pristine Li foil and current density during deposition was large, it showed uneven deposition at the beginning (Fig. 4(h)). Through the above research, it can be seen that Ag-Graphite@Li foil could induce to penetrate the graphite layer for deposition, which had realized the protection of Li metal and uniform deposition. It also helps to build a stable electrode-electrolyte interface and to achieve a better electrochemical performance of LMBs.

The in-situ EIS of symmetrical cells of pristine Li metal anode, Graphite@Li anode and Ag-Graphite@Li anode were tested to study the interfacial stability of three anodes during cycling. The Autolab electrochemical workstation was used to test the resistance values of different batteries before cycle and after the 1st, 3rd, 5th, 10th, 50th, and 100th cycle. The resistance value can be seen as the interface transmission resistance (Rt) of Li+ ions. The smaller the Rt, the easier it is for Li+ ions to transport at the interface. That is, the smaller Rt can enable Li+ ions to reach the anode more quickly to obtain electron and deposit, which can effectively promote uniform Li deposition and inhibit Li dendrites formation. The stability of SEI at different anode interfaces can be seen by the change of Rt of the batteries after different cycles. On the pristine Li metal anode, the Rt increased rapidly from 54.3 Ω to 118.6 Ω after the first cycle. This indicated that the SEI generated by the first cycle on the pristine Li metal anode was inhomogeneous and structurally unstable, resulting in a rapid Rt increase. After ten cycles, the Rt also showed a steady increase. After a long cycle of 50 and 100 cycles, the Rt values reached 359.7 Ω and 553.2 Ω, respectively ( Fig. 5(a)). It showed that during the cycling, the uneven Li plating/stripping process on the pristine Li metal anode will cause repeated rupture and regeneration of SEI, resulting in continuous thickening and extremely uneven composition distribution of SEI. It made the pristine Li metal anode unable to maintain interface stability, resulting in a rapid increase in Rt. On the Graphite@Li metal anode, its Rt value increased from 35.2 Ω to 42.5 Ω after the first cycle. After 10 cycles, the Rt was 84.3 Ω, which was slightly lower than that of the pristine Li metal anode. However, as the cycle increases, the Rt values reached 186.7 Ω and 296.8 Ω after 50 and 100 cycles, respectively (Fig. 5(b)). On the Ag-Graphite@Li metal anode, the Rt after the 1st and 10th cycle was 28.5 Ω and 53.4 Ω respectively, which were lower than that of the other two anodes. After 50–100 cycles, the Rt increased from 126.3 to 203.6 Ω (Fig. 5(c)). These Rt values were at a low level and there is no clear growth trend. This showed, stable Li plating/stripping process can be formed on the Ag-Graphite@Li anode for the presence of the modification layer, thereby avoiding repeated rupture and regeneration and thickness increase of SEI. The result was a stable SEI composition and structure, and the Rt value can be kept a low level.

Then three anodes were equipped with symmetrical batteries for electrochemical performance testing, with a cycle current density of 1 mA cm−2 and a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. In the pristine Li anode, the polarization voltage of the symmetrical battery began to gradually increase after a stable cycle of 1000 h. The cycle lifespan of the Graphite@Li anode was only about 1400 h. However, Ag-Graphite@Li anode can achieve a stable cycle of 2200 h, and its lifetime was longer than other two anodes (Fig. 5(d)). At about 400 h in the early cycle, the polarization voltage of the three anodes was basically maintained at about 20 mV, and no significant difference was shown (Fig. 5(e1), (f1), (g1)). When the cycle time reached 1200 h, the polarization voltage of the pristine Li metal anode increased to 75 mV (Fig. 5(e2)). This value has far exceeded the previous 20 mV, indicating that the pristine Li anode can no longer achieve stable cycling at this time. For Graphite@Li anode, the polarization voltage of a cyclic 1200 h battery increased to 25 mV, indicating that its interface began to show an unstable tendency (Fig. 5(f2)). For Ag-Graphite@Li anode, the polarization voltage was still about 20 mV when cycling to 1200 h. It showed that Ag-Graphite@Li anode can achieve a stable electrochemical cycle (Fig. 5(g2)). The symmetrical battery data showed that Ag-Graphite@Li foil could obtain a stable anode interface during cycling, which was beneficial to improve the electrochemical performance of the battery.

The electrochemical performance of the cathode half-cell equipped with NCM523 (mass loading was about 13.5–14.0 mg cm−2, voltage range was from 2.75 V to 4.3 V) was tested. For the pristine Li metal anode, the discharge capacity began to decay rapidly after 200 cycles ( Fig. 6(a)). This is mainly due to uneven Li deposition and repeated generation of unstable SEI film. For the Graphite@Li anode, the discharge capacity of the half-cell had a stable decreasing tendency (Fig. 6(e)). It was difficult for the anode modified by graphite alone to obtain a stable interface during the cycling process, making it hard to achieve a sustainable stable electrochemical cycling. For the Ag-Graphite@Li anode, the battery expressed a high capacity retention rate of 78.3 % after 400 cycles, showing better electrochemical performance than the other two anodes (Fig. 6(b)). At the rate of 1.0 C, the three anodes also exhibited the similar electrochemical performance (Fig. S7). The reason for the long lifespan is that Ag layer can induce Li+ ions to penetrate the graphite layer for deposition, while the outer graphite layer can build a SEI with a clear composition and stable structure to help achieve a stable electrode/electrolyte interface.

SEM was used to observe the morphology of the three LMAs after 10th and 50th cycles, respectively. It can be seen that after 10th cycles on the Ag-Graphite@Li foil, the anode surface still showed a smooth morphology without Li dendrites and dead Li formation (Fig. 6(c)). There were only some micropores produced by the plating and stripping of Li metal in the inner layer of graphite, which also indicated that Li+ ions can achieve penetrating deposition on the Ag-Graphite@Li foil. After 50th cycles, the anode surface was still flat, and there was no obvious Li dendrites and dead Li (Fig. 6(d)). On Graphite@Li foil, due to the uneven deposition of metal Li on the graphite surface, visible dead Li and Li dendrites are formed on the surface after 10th cycles (Fig. 6(f)). Meanwhile, the unstable plating and stripping of Li metal made the amount of dead Li on the anode increase significantly after 50th cycles, and a large number of lithium dendrites appeared on the surface (Fig. 6(g)). The presence of such a large amount of Li dendrites and dead Li will make the Coulombic efficiency rapidly decrease, and naturally it was impossible to have a long stable cycle of the battery. On pristine Li surface, the uneven plating and stripping behavior of Li metal lead to the formation of a loose and porous structure, and there were also some fine cracks on the electrode surface (Fig. 6(i)). After 50th cycles, huge cracks a number of dead Li have appeared on the surface, resulting in the decrease of electrochemical performance (Fig. 6(j)). Through the morphology observation of three LMAs after different cycles, it can be seen that Li metal on Ag-Graphite@Li foil can achieve stable deposition and peeling behavior due to the induction of lithiophilic Ag NPs and keep a flat and stable anode surface. Meanwhile, the graphite layer induced the formation of stable SEI film, and the combined action help to realize the construction of a stable electrode-electrolyte interface.

In summary, a stable Ag-Graphite@Li metal anode was constructed by simple vacuum evaporation and manual coating. The induction of the Ag layer helps to achieve embedded Li deposition, thereby protecting Li metal and achieving a stable interface. Meanwhile, graphite layer can promote the rapid and uniform film formation of carbonate electrolytes. Under the combined action, a stable composition and uniform structure of SEI were constructed on Ag-Graphite@Li metal anode to help realize a long lifespan LMB. On this basis, Ag-Graphite@Li foil symmetrical battery showed a cycle life of more than 2200 h in carbonate electrolyte, which is higher than pure Li-Li symmetric battery of only 600 h. And Ag-Graphite@Li metal anode//NCM523 cell could maintain a capacity retention of 78.3 % for 400 cycles at 0.5 C in carbonate-based electrolytes. Under the joint action of Ag layer and graphite layer, the construction of stable SEI on the anode surface was realized. This design provides a new way for the realization of LMBs with high energy density.
